Trump Organization: Lawsuit Filed Over DC Hotel Is Routine "... refuses to pay the sums due ..." by Jack Davis January 25, 2017 at 5:51pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Noting that the opening of President Donald Trump’s Washington hotel was linked to his efforts to win the White House, a contractor is suing Trump for $2 million in costs to open the hotel at the Old Post Office Building. 
The Trump Organization released a statement suggesting such suits are part of doing business. 
AES Electrical, also known as Freestate Electrical, contends it had to engage in “nonstop” work so the Trump International Hotel could open on time. Advertisement - story continues below Trump Says Waterboarding ‘Absolutely’ Works, But He’ll Let Cabinet Decide Whether To Reinstate It 
The lawsuit was filed Thursday, the day before Trump’s inauguration. 
“Acceleration of Freestate’s work required Freestate’s crews to work nonstop, seven days per week, 10 to 14 hours per day for nearly 50 consecutive days, prior to the ‘soft opening,’ at significant additional cost and expense for which Freestate expected payment,” according to the complaint . 
“Subsequent to the Hotel’s ‘soft opening,’ Freestate was required to continue its acceleration efforts and the performance of extra work in order to permit the ‘grand opening’ of the Trump Hotel by Oct. 26, 2016,” the complaint adds. Advertisement - story continues below 
The complaint makes multiple references to Trump’s campaign. 
“The ‘grand opening’ of the Trump Hotel by this day, was also a nationally covered event, which was planned just prior to the U.S. presidential election,” the suit states. 
“Although Mr. Trump’s Hotel has now been opened and has operated for business since September 2016, and despite the fact that Mr. Trump was successfully elected as the next U.S. President, Trump refuses to pay the sums due for the account of work of subcontractors, like Freestate,” the complaint says. 
The contractor alleges the Trump Organization will only settle for a fraction of the cost. Advertisement - story continues below Trump Announces Investigation To Prove Claims On Voter Fraud 
The Trump Organization downplayed the suit. 
“In developments of this scale and complexity, the filing of nominal liens at the conclusion of construction is not uncommon as part of the closeout process,” the statement said. 
“In the case of Trump International Hotel, Washington D.C., the Trump Organization has invested over $200 million into the redevelopment of the historic Old Post Office and is incredibly proud of what is now considered to be one the most iconic hotels anywhere in the country,” the statement added. 
At the time the hotel opened, Trump noted that by coming in under budget and ahead of schedule, the hotel was an example of what he could do for the country. 
“This was just under budget, ahead of schedule. That’s what this is. Under budget, ahead of schedule. We built a hotel that is going to be one of the great hotels of the world. Just opened today. It officially opens today, and we built it for less money than was anticipated and we built it ahead of schedule by over a year. And if the country would do that, we would have a country that would be in much better shape than it’s — you know, highways, they build highways for double and triple the cost, they build hospitals,” he said then. 
“I want the American people to understand that this is under budget, ahead of schedule, and we need that for the United States,” he added.
